ROBERT FIELD: So molecules
have three kinds of structures.

Electronic, vibrational,
and rotational. And my goal is to
give you a sense

of how do we predict
each kind of structure?

Not how do we calculate it, but
how do you have it in your head so that you know what are
the expected patterns,

and how do you use one
pattern to help you

with a decision about what
another pattern means? So electronic structure
is a combination

of big stuff and small stuff. The big stuff is basically
the spectrum of hydrogen,

or the spectrum of H2
plus molecular ions,

that these are one
kind of pattern that is possible to remember, but
the more electrons we have,

the more complicated
that will be. But it's useful to have a simple
picture of what it ought to be

and how it gets disguised. But there are little
things too that also provide crucial clues what
the electronic structure is.

Like fine structure,
hyperfine structure, spin orbit, spin
spin, spin rotation.

Things where the spectrum
gets a little complicated, but it's really
small splittings,

and often they
tell you a lot more about the nature
of the state you're looking at that the big stuff.

And so if you want to be
able to deal with both. And so I'm going to present my
unique view of atomic spectra,

with the view of making it
useful to you for understanding what you're going to encounter
in molecular structure.

AUDIENCE: Can I ask
one quick question now? ROBERT FIELD: Yeah. AUDIENCE: So we talk about
electronic vibrational

and rotational structure, and
typically only these three. And by electronic
structure, we really mean like valence
electronic structure.

So basically, is
the reason we don't talk about spectra
of core electrons

because it's experimentally
hard to make X-rays, or is it because it's really,
really not as interesting?

And similarly, do we not talk
about the nuclear magnetic resonance type spectra because
it doesn't really affect these

other motions , or because
you need a big magnet? ROBERT FIELD: The
simple answer is

we don't talk about that,
because I don't know that. Not like as well as I
know these other things.

The core structure, when we
excite to very highly excited

electronic states by
opening up the core, the molecule is never stable. And so you end up
having continua.

But in some ways,
the core structure is simpler, because the cores
don't know their in a molecule.

Or they only know they're
in a particular molecule through fine structures. And so they are wonderful probes
of the chemical environment

of a particular atom. And that is useful. But it's not complicated, in the
sense that assigning a spectrum

is complicated. Basically, you know where
each cell has its spectra.

And each atom has its
different end shells at different energies.

And so you don't need me to
help you to assign such spectra. Those are very easy.

It's the kind of
spectra that most people who are not physical chemists
think all spectra would be.

Things that are very,
very low resolution, very simple to interpret,
and have direct chemical

significance. NMR is of great importance,
usually for larger molecules

where you want to know
what's connected to what.

The kind of thing that
I'm talking to you about is you know pretty much
what the bonded network is,

and you have some
ideas about what the structure of the
molecules would be.

There may be times when you have
spectra of different molecules,

and you'd like to sort them out
according to which is which. And in that sense,
NMR might be of use,

but usually nobody does
NMR in the gas phase, because it's a magnetic
dipole non-transition.

It's weak, and you
need a lot of molecules in order to get NMR spectra.

So I think the communities who
use core structure and NMR are

different from the
physical chemists, mostly that are going to be
concerned with the spectra

of small-ish molecules
in the gas phase. But that was a
really good question.

OK, so we want to
ask two questions

when we approach a spectrum. What do we expect, and when
should we be surprised?

Because if the spectrum is
entirely what we expect, well, then, there isn't
really any challenge. And there isn't anything new.

But if we're surprised, you
need to you should be surprised, and that the molecule
is telling you something

that is worth figuring out. Because it's violating
some rule, or it's doing something really neat.

And so being surprised is good. And so I'm going to begin
talking about patterns

of levels,
transitions, and we're

going to talk about good quantum
numbers, and things like that.

OK. But the way we're
going to start is we're going to talk
about one-electron atoms.

In other words, hydrogen
atom, helium plus ion, lithium 2 plus ion.

And these are all
really simple things, but they illustrate that
electronic structure doesn't

have to be a
telephone directory. It can be just a bunch
of related things,

and if you know one,
you know the other. And then life gets
more complicated

when we go beyond
one-electron atoms. So we're going to talk about
one-electron atoms, the terms of the Hamiltonian,
the basis functions

we use to express the
Hamiltonian, various kinds of scaling rules that tell
you how properties depend

on quantum numbers. So notation and transition
propensity rules.

For example, we have the
atomic angular momentum j for a transition, and the
atomic orbital angular momentum

l, the propensity
rule says that delta j

ought to be equal
to tell the delta l. j changes by plus 1,
l changes by plus 1.

You can have things
violating propensity rules, but the stronger
transitions are this,

and you get that
from a vector model. And I'll introduce you
to a vector model, which

is the beginning of using
these precessing vectors, or things that usually,
when you start to see them,

you say, I want
out of this room, because I don't really
know what these vectors are

and why I'm forced to
memorize these things. OK. So after we do
one-electron atoms,
we'll do alkali-like atoms.

And those are atoms with one
electron outside of a closed shell. And they differ from
the one-electron atoms

in an important way, a
simple way, and that's the first step into complexity.

And we'll eventually get
to many-electron atoms.

And then we have to
do more work to relate what we see in the
spectrum to the things
you'd like to understand.

And once we get to
alkali-like atoms, there's going to be a little
bit of quantum defect theory.

It's a topic I'm going to
come back to repeatedly in increasing sophistication.

Basically, as chemists, we
know about quantum mechanics

a little bit. We know about
Hamiltonians, and most of my approach to the
problem is in terms

of effective Hamiltonians,
which are just a toy version of the real thing.

There is another approach,
which is more of a physicist approach, which is scattering.

And there is a way of
using scattering to learn about the structure of things.

And that's where quantum
defect theory comes in, and it's more powerful for
certain classes of problems
and we'll see that. OK. So bottom of page one.

The one-electron atoms
are called hydrogenic, so the Hamiltonian is a function
of spherical, or coordinates,

and spin coordinates,
which are just something that we don't really
know what they are.

And so it's a central
force problem. And central force
problems are all related.

And the Hamiltonian is
expressed in this way.

We have Ze squared over r
cubed 2p squared c squared.
Ls.
So this is the kinetic energy. This is the potential energy.

And this is my very
good friend spin orbit. It's an example of
small stuff that

helps you a lot in
understanding what's going on. So it's perhaps an extra
level of complexity,

but it's something
that we care about. Now, one of the neat things
you notice right away

is this is 1 over r cubed. And so that actually
turns out to be

a very important simplification,
because it says spin orbit. Whatever that is happens
near the nucleus.

And we don't care that much
about what's going on outside. So it is if it's happening
near the nucleus,

it's where things
are pretty simple. And so this is why it's
such a valuable probe.

OK. Kinetic energy. Well, there are a lot of
things in the kinetic energy,

and one of them is
angular momentum.

So we have orbital
angular momentum that's included
in here, and when

we write a basis
set, which includes L as one of the quantum numbers,
that part of the angular

momentum has this form, we still
have r squared as a variable.

But this is now
a quantum number, and this has taken the angular
part of the problem out.

And we have now something
that, although it comes from the
kinetic energy, we

stick it into this,
the potential energy. and we say we have an
effective potential, which

is a function of r alone. And so it's a central
force problem,

which has been dressed
up with something that has some angular momentum.

And so we say this generates
a centrifugal barrier. Why is it a barrier? Because it's a positive, as
r gets small, this gets big.

And so it's a barrier that
keeps the electrons from getting in close to the nucleus.

So we have a central
force problem, and the wave function
can be written

as a product of two
factors, an angular

factor and a radial factor. Now, for all central
problems, you
get the same negative effect. And so this is universal.

And this radial factor is
unique to the particular atom,

but not when you have
one-electron atoms. It's basically the
same thing, it's only scaled by the
charge on the atom.

So for one-electron an
atom, this is universal. But generally, the
wave function is

divided into a universal
angular momentum factor, a system-specific
radial factor, which

is where all the
interesting stuff is, but a lot of the
manipulations get out of here.
OK. So Z is charge of a nucleus.

Yes? AUDIENCE: Could
you just remind me how we actually
include that spin

orbit into the Hamiltonian? Because I guess I'm still
thinking like potential energy and kinetic energy.

ROBERT FIELD: Well, OK. The Hamiltonian is the energy. And so anything that contributes
to the energy of the state

gets put into the Hamiltonian. So you're right to say, I
know where this comes from.

It's actually a
relativistic effect.

But the convenient thing is
that it behaves as l dot s,

the orbital angular
movement got into the spin. And it's the angular
momentum and the spin of the same electron.

And so I'm not going
to derive these things. I've got to tell you. Because many courses you
see the lengthy derivations

and you don't see
what they're for. So this is just a contribution
to the energy that happens

for atoms and molecules. There are other
smaller contributions, like hyperfine, where you have
the electron with its orbital

and spinning and
all that, and it interacts with the behavioral
momentum of the nucleus.

And that's at a bar,
well that's not-- AUDIENCE: Can we
think about this as a potential energy
of the spin being

in the magnetic field, created
by its own rotation, so on this? ROBERT FIELD: You can do
that, but it's a little bit

dangerous, because we
associate a magnetic dipole with the orbital angular
momentum and with the spin.

And so this looks like a
dipole-dipole interaction, but it isn't quite.

Because when it's a
relativistic effect,

it has to do with
the electron moving very fast near the nucleus.

And I can't really explain
it any better than that. And it scales with
the nuclear charge.

And a simple dipole-dipole
interaction wouldn't do that. But if you think of it as two
magnetic dipoles interacting,

you get the operator form,
but not the magnitude. But that's OK.

So we're always thinking in
terms into the Hamiltonian, because we need them. Or we're taking
them out, because we

assume they weren't there. But this is a really
good question. OK, so now, I have to
define some things.

This is the charge
in the nucleus, and so for hydrogen, it's one. And for helium plus, it's 2.

And I want to make
a distinction. You might have a particle.

Well, for one-electron
systems, it is the charge on the nucleus. But for many electron
alkali-like systems,

it is not necessarily either
an integer or the charge,

either the ion core,
or the nucleus itself.

And so this turns into a
fudge factor in a few minutes. But for one-electron systems,
it's not a fudge factor.

This is the reduced mass. And reduced mass is
the mass of the nucleus

times the mass of the electron
over the mass of the electron plus the mass of the nucleus.

And this is always really
small compared to this. And so if you throw
that away, this

becomes just the mass
of the electrons. OK, so this reduced mass
factor is almost exactly

the mass of the electron,
but it isn't exactly, because this is not zero. And so if you change the
nuclear mass from 100 to 200,

you can do that. There will be a very, very small
effect on this reduced mass.

And one of the
neat things is, OK, that's going to
change the energy levels by an amount that's
proportional to how much

the reduced mass has changed. And so it changes maybe
by part in a thousand.

Well, that's pretty small. But in electronic spectroscopy,
we measure things typically to a part in a million.

So it starts to make a
significant difference, one atom versus another.

So it's not just the
mass of the electron,

but so there's a little
bit of stuff there. OK, now, we have two choices
of basis sets, in which we

can look at this problem. And this thing
here is the reason

why we talk about basis sets
and a choice of basis sets, and that there's one good choice
and one not such a good choice.

And so the uncoupled basis
set is written as l ml s ms,

and the coupled one
is written as l sj mj.

So what is this? These are shorthand for
eigenvalues of operators

that commute with
each other, and they

commute with the zero
order Hamiltonian if they're going to
be basis functions. So the angular momentum,
total angular momentum,

orbital angular with
l squared gives you l, lz gives you ml, et cetera.

And j is the vector
sum of l and s.

So we have these
angular momentum things. This is an eigenfunction
of l squared

where the eigenvalue of
l squared is Ll plus 1.

So we don't write Ll
plus 1 in here, we write l because it takes less

And the eigenvalue for
l sub z is m sub l. lz operand, this gives the
function back, m sub l.

So we have these
building blocks, and with them, whenever we
see any angular momentum

in this problem, we can work out

So we can write the components
of l as lz plus lx plus ly.

But we like to write

because they're neat. Because they're analogous to

And l minus is lx minus ily.

And l dot s is lzsz plus one

and s do commute, and

So we don't have to

And l plus, operating

gives back lm plus 1 minus--

now, this is just like harmonic

And so what goes in
